author: By Lisa Lerer
title: This Is the Week Trump’s Been Waiting For
description: But will Republicans’ celebration of their president deliver the agenda-setting boost he needs?
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
title: Biden and Harris, in their first interview, dismiss questions about their differences.
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Kamala Harris presented a united front in their first joint television interview, glossing over a number of significant differences they held in the primary campaign to emphasize their shared commitment to defeating President Trump.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Kamala Harris presented a united front in their first joint television interview, glossing over a number of significant differences they held in the primary campaign to emphasize their shared commitment to defeating President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Frances Robles
title: Puerto Rican officials tested positive for the coronavirus after indoor campaign events.
description: In Puerto Rico, several high-ranking politicians contracted the coronavirus after attending indoor campaign events, offering a cautionary tale for the Republican convention and future campaign stops.
content: In Puerto Rico, several high-ranking politicians contracted the coronavirus after attending indoor campaign events, offering a cautionary tale for the Republican convention and future campaign stops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: QAnon Is Trump’s Last, Best Chance
description: The only thing he can hope for is fear itself.
content: Last week’s Democratic National Convention was mainly about decency — about portraying Joe Biden and his party as good people who will do their best to heal a nation afflicted by a pandemic and a depression. There were plenty of dire warnings about the threat of Trumpism; there was frank acknowledgment of the toll taken by disease and unemployment; but on the whole the message was surprisingly upbeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Insurer Drops Whistle-Blower Lawyer, Citing High-Profile Work
description: The decision shows some of the risks for government whistle-blowers and those who work to support them.
content: A lawyer for the government whistle-blower whose concerns about President Trump’s dealings with Ukraine sparked impeachment proceedings has been dropped by his malpractice insurer because his underwriter said it had no “appetite” for his “high-profile” work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: New York’s School Chaos Is Breaking Me
description: So this is how it feels to be abandoned by your government.
content: I’m writing this column at 4 a.m., because I can’t sleep, again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: California’s Crises Converge: Fleeing Wildfires in a Pandemic
description: Monday: Catch up on news of the wildfires burning across California.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Finn and Richard Malley
title: A Vaccine That Stops Covid-19 Won’t Be Enough
description: The best vaccines don’t just prevent a disease; they also prevent the pathogen causing the disease from being transmitted. So why aren’t we focusing more on those?
content: Not long after the new coronavirus first surfaced last December, an ambitious prediction was made: A vaccine would be available within 12 to 18 months, and it would stop the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Kansas Candidate Who Admitted to Revenge Porn Plans to Withdraw
description: Aaron Coleman, 19, won the Democratic primary election for a Kansas House seat by 14 votes. Now he wants out.
content: The 19-year-old candidate for the Kansas Legislature who admitted to sending revenge porn and bullying girls online when he was in middle school plans to withdraw as the Democratic nominee, he announced on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Dream of Historic Feasts
description: With the help of the 92nd Street Y, the historian Francine Segan will recount feasts from ancient Egypt, Greece and Rome, along with Victorian England, recipes included.
content: As you sit at home with that bowl of mac and cheese, you might enjoy some more lavish vicarious treats. The 92nd Street Y has scheduled a course of virtual hourlong talks about the feasts of yore, in Cleopatra’s Egypt, in ancient Greece under Alexander the Great, in gluttonous Roman times during Caesar’s reign, and in Victorian England. The classes, by the food historian Francine Segan, will include easy recipes for foods of those eras to make at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Hong Kong reinfection, TikTok, Philippines explosions: Here’s what you need to know.
content: A 33-year-old man was infected a second time more than four months after he initially contracted the coronavirus, a team at the University of Hong Kong said on Monday. After getting sick in Hong Kong in March, he tested positive on Aug. 15 after a trip to Spain via the United Kingdom, picking up a strain that was circulating in Europe in July and August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum and Danny Hakim
title: N.Y. Attorney General Asks Judge to Order Eric Trump’s Testimony
description: The Trump Organization has stalled a state inquiry into the financing of four properties for months, Attorney General Letitia James said in court papers.
content: The New York State attorney general’s office has stepped up its inquiry into whether President Trump and the Trump Organization committed fraud by overstating assets to get loans and tax benefits, asking a judge to order Eric Trump to answer questions under oath and the company to hand over documents, court papers show.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Risks if Biden Loses
description: A reader calls the former vice president our best hope to right the wrongs of the last four years. Also: Oil leasing in the Arctic refuge; Lori Loughlin’s jail sentence; prisoner firefighters; Trump donors.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Marco Spares Gulf Coast, Which Is Bracing for Tropical Storm Laura
description: While Louisiana’s governor said the region caught a big break as Tropical Storm Marco faded, evacuation orders were issued as communities prepared for Laura’s strength.
content: ATLANTA — Tropical Storm Marco significantly weakened before making landfall on Monday night, largely sparing the Gulf Coast from the “one-two punch” of back-to-back hurricanes that meteorologists had warned might pummel Louisiana and Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: India Building Collapse Leaves Scores Trapped in Debris
description: At least 17 people were injured in the collapse of an apartment building, according to news reports, and about 30 people were pulled to safety.
content: MUMBAI — Dozens of people were feared trapped in the debris of a five-story building that collapsed on Monday in Mahad, an industrial town in western India, with some reports saying about 60 to 70 people were still inside, while a local lawmaker said the figure was higher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: A New Mexico House seat that flipped to a Democrat in 2018 is back in play.
description: LAS CRUCES, N.M. — When Democrats in New Mexico swept elections just two years ago, flipping a Republican-held congressional district that stretches across more than half the state ranked among their biggest wins.
content: LAS CRUCES, N.M. — When Democrats in New Mexico swept elections just two years ago, flipping a Republican-held congressional district that stretches across more than half the state ranked among their biggest wins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift Spends a Fourth Week at No. 1 Thanks to Full Album Sales
description: “Folklore” has now sold the equivalent of 1.2 million copies, taking into account sales and streams.
content: Rappers, your streaming numbers may be gigantic, but when it comes to the Billboard album chart they are no match for an autographed Taylor Swift CD placed on the counter of an indie record store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Over two dozen Republicans who served in Congress endorse Biden.
description: Swaying disillusioned Republicans and unaffiliated voters has become a point of emphasis for former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., whose campaign released on Monday a list of 27 former Republican members of Congress who had endorsed him against President Trump.
content: Swaying disillusioned Republicans and unaffiliated voters has become a point of emphasis for former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., whose campaign released on Monday a list of 27 former Republican members of Congress who had endorsed him against President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Politicizing Medical Science Will Cost American Lives
description: Sowing doubt about the safety of treatments will imperil the fight against coronavirus in the months and years to come.
content: The Food and Drug Administration is no stranger to political interference. Special interests have played as much of a role as actual data in the approval of questionable cancer drugs and faulty medical devices for almost as long as the agency has existed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Unemployment Is Rampant. So This Theater Is Giving Freelancers Money.
description: Several hundred workers are receiving $1,000 relief payments from the Public Theater.
content: The Public Theater, a leading Off Broadway nonprofit, is giving small grants to several hundred freelance artists as many grapple with the impact of joblessness and expiring unemployment benefits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This Chocolate Liqueur Is a Keeper
description: Organic Mixology’s new chocolate and sea salt liqueur adds a sophisticated note to cocktails like the sidecar.
content: Organic Mixology, or OM, a line of intriguing liqueurs in combinations like Meyer Lemon & Ginger, has introduced a Dark Chocolate & Sea Salt flavor. This is not your often-cloying garden-variety chocolate spirit, but one that showcases the bitterness of dark chocolate, with the salt a subtle grace note. The company suggests using it in a sidecar or espresso martini, but I successfully added a splash to an iced coffee shakerato. And I was pleased at how nicely it came through in a 3-2-1 cocktail of dark rum, chocolate liqueur and elderflower liqueur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A new study from Hong Kong details the first documented case of reinfection.
content: It’s official: Humans can get reinfected with the coronavirus. The first documented case is a 33-year-old man in Hong Kong who caught the virus at the end of March and, more than four months later, picked it up again during a trip to Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Remembering Odetta, Whose Powerful Voice Met a Profound Moment
description: Ian Zack’s “Odetta” and Matthew Frye Jacobson’s “One Grain of Sand” assess the legacy of the singer, whose career intertwined with the civil rights movement.
content: In the biography of nearly every white rock performer of a certain vintage, there’s a pivotal moment — more pivotal than signing the ill-advised first contract that leads to decades of litigation, and more pivotal than the first social disease. The moment is when the subject watched Elvis Presley’s appearance on “The Ed Sullivan Show” on Sept. 9, 1956.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith and Tariq Panja
title: Soccer Played Through the Pandemic. Now It Has to Do It All Again.
description: Strict rules and player sacrifices allowed Europe’s leagues to complete their schedules. But the coronavirus hasn’t abated, and the new season brings new risks.
content: Jonathan Van-Tam made no attempt to sugarcoat it. Amid soccer’s coronavirus hiatus, as sports leagues around the world tried to figure out a way to return to the field as a pandemic raged, Van-Tam, the deputy chief medical officer of Britain, had been invited to join a Zoom call with the captains of the Premier League’s 20 clubs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Aug. 24, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 24, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 24, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
title: Kellyanne Conway is leaving the White House.
description: Kellyanne Conway, President Trump’s counselor and one of his longest-serving aides, said on Sunday night that she planned to leave the White House next week.
content: Kellyanne Conway, President Trump’s counselor and one of his longest-serving aides, said on Sunday night that she planned to leave the White House next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Pence tells the convention he and Trump will defend borders and the ‘right to life.’
description: Vice President Mike Pence took the stage to accept his renomination Monday morning as the Republican National Convention kicked off, pitching the Trump-Pence ticket as leaders of a party that stood for “free market economics, secure borders” and the “right to life.”
content: Vice President Mike Pence took the stage to accept his renomination Monday morning as the Republican National Convention kicked off, pitching the Trump-Pence ticket as leaders of a party that stood for “free market economics, secure borders” and the “right to life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Corn With a Purple Blush
description: Wild violet corn is a new seasonal offering from Baldor Specialty Foods.
content: Ears of corn with purple kernels among the gold are new on the market from Baldor Specialty Foods, the wholesale company that has been delivering to retail customers during the pandemic. The corn, which comes already shucked in packs of four, is grown in Florida and New Jersey. It has the meaty, rich flavor and texture of mature corn. Baldor also carries baby corn, ears 3- to 6-inches long, sold in the husk. It’s not a dwarf variety, but regular sweet corn grown at Alewife Farm in Kingston, N.Y., and picked very young; even the central cob is tender. The smallest ones can be enjoyed raw in an assortment of crudités; larger ones are better sliced thin into a stir-fry or taco, or parboiled whole and served as a side dish. The season on these new varieties will extend into September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Born to the Internet, Grew Up Fast in a Pandemic
description: When traditional college jobs suddenly went away, these students used their ingenuity to find new ways to pay the bills.
content: A junior at Texas State University lost his jobs as a bartender and a barista when the pandemic started. Now he sells instant ramen and CBD-infused baked goods that he makes in his kitchen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: Climate Is Taking On a Growing Role for Voters, Research Suggests
description: Concern about global warming is steady despite other crises, a survey found, and the number of voters who are deeply engaged on the issue is rising sharply.
content: The number of Americans who feel passionately about climate change is rising sharply, and the issue appears likely to play a more important role in this year’s election than ever before, a new survey shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: After a week of setbacks, Trump hopes to change the story line.
description: When President Trump’s strategists mapped out their plans for the critical week leading to the Republican National Convention that would nominate him for a second term, the schedule somehow did not include a sensational arrest on a Chinese billionaire’s yacht.
content: When President Trump’s strategists mapped out their plans for the critical week leading to the Republican National Convention that would nominate him for a second term, the schedule somehow did not include a sensational arrest on a Chinese billionaire’s yacht.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: DeJoy Defends Postal Changes as Trump Continues to Attack Voting by Mail
description: Facing tough questioning from a House panel, the postmaster general denounced suggestions that he was working to help President Trump politically and defended the cost-cutting changes he has overseen.
content: Postmaster General Louis DeJoy told Congress on Monday that the Postal Service could be trusted to carry out the largest vote-by-mail program in American history without political bias, even as President Trump repeated baseless accusations that mail-in voting would be used by his rivals to rig the November election against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Frakt
title: The Fine Line Between Choice and Confusion in Health Care
description: Part of the U.S. debate over health care is really a debate over the definition of freedom.
content: American opponents of proposed government-run health systems have long used the word “choice” as a weapon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: The One-Man Show Begins
description: President Trump takes center stage at the R.N.C.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Giovanni Russonello, typically the morning newsletter writer, covering the evening shift during the conventions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses and Geneva Abdul
title: Reluctant to vacation abroad, Britons are pitching a tent and sticking close to home.
description: Across England, in numbers that travel businesses say they had rarely seen before, lockdown-freed Britons are not only staying close to home this vacation season but spending it in motor homes, campers, campsites and glampsites. Vacationers are turning to camping as the holiday of choice for some social distancing in the great outdoors.
content: Across England, in numbers that travel businesses say they had rarely seen before, lockdown-freed Britons are not only staying close to home this vacation season but spending it in motor homes, campers, campsites and glampsites. Vacationers are turning to camping as the holiday of choice for some social distancing in the great outdoors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Usain Bolt Quarantines as He Awaits Result of Coronavirus Test
description: The Olympic great from Jamaica said he would keep to himself for two weeks, but that he felt no symptoms of the virus.
content: Usain Bolt, the Olympic great who won eight gold medals over the course of three Olympics, will quarantine while awaiting results from a coronavirus test he took on Saturday, the sprinter said in an Instagram post on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: Trump hasn’t tried much to expand his base. Will he change that this week?
description: Four years ago, President Trump accepted the Republican presidential nomination in Cleveland over persistent opposition within his own party. There was a hopeless, last-minute effort to battle his nomination on the convention floor. There was Senator Ted Cruz’s admonition to voters to “vote your conscience,” in lieu of a call for party unity. There was Gov. John Kasich — the chief executive of the host state — declining to attend.
content: Four years ago, President Trump accepted the Republican presidential nomination in Cleveland over persistent opposition within his own party. There was a hopeless, last-minute effort to battle his nomination on the convention floor. There was Senator Ted Cruz’s admonition to voters to “vote your conscience,” in lieu of a call for party unity. There was Gov. John Kasich — the chief executive of the host state — declining to attend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanya Yanagihara
title: Rethinking Who and What Get Memorialized
description: The notion that history can be rewritten is a powerful one. It starts by taking the pen from the authors we’ve always had — and giving it to someone else.
content: This is a magazine devoted to documenting visual culture, whether those visuals come from the worlds of fashion, theater, film, architecture or art. Some of the most striking visuals from the past half-year in America — and there have been many — have concerned the removal or defacement of monuments dedicated to figures from the Confederacy, whose placement in public spaces mostly in the South are, for many of us, an insult, if not an assault. I am not Black, but I keenly remember the discomfort and inexplicable shame I often felt while attending my freshman-year public high school, Robert E. Lee, in Tyler, Texas. Lee was a Confederate general, a slave owner and a commander in the Confederate Army during the American Civil War. (The middle school I attended in Tyler, Hubbard, was also named for a former Confederate officer, who later became the state’s governor.) A large portrait of Lee hung in the school gym, and whenever I saw it, I felt as if my right to this country, to Americanness, was being challenged. Why, more than a century later, was someone who had fought for something this country now purported to be against still being honored?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Taliban Tighten ‘Ring of Siege’ Around Afghan Capital
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 24, 2020.
content: “The Taliban go to people and ask them for food, and no one can say no. If people say they don’t have enough food, the Taliban ask them to butcher their animals and feed them.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: College Reopening: The Outlook for In-Person Classes
description: A look at how U.S. colleges and universities are starting the semester, and the challenges for students with special needs.
content: In a matter of days, nearly all U.S. colleges and universities will be back in session — whether it’s online, in person, or some combination. Davidson College and The Chronicle of Higher Education are tracking the reopening plans of nearly 3,000 institutions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Even before Falwell resigned, he was not invited back to the Republican convention.
description: Jerry Falwell Jr. played a major role at the Republican National Convention four years ago, serving as a critical bridge between conservative evangelical voters and a Republican nominee who was thrice divorced, enamored of expletive, iffy on biblical verse, and a one-time Democrat who had proudly declared himself  “pro-choice in every respect” before changing positions and parties.
content: Jerry Falwell Jr. played a major role at the Republican National Convention four years ago, serving as a critical bridge between conservative evangelical voters and a Republican nominee who was thrice divorced, enamored of expletive, iffy on biblical verse, and a one-time Democrat who had proudly declared himself  “pro-choice in every respect” before changing positions and parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Networks’ Challenge: Covering a Live Convention When Falsehoods Fly
description: President Trump lobbed unsubstantiated claims during his Monday speech in Charlotte, N.C. TV broadcasters are trying to balance voters’ right to hear directly from their president with efforts to keep viewers informed of the facts.
content: Television’s ability to handle a Trump-centric Republican National Convention faced an early test on Monday, when the president delivered a kickoff speech in Charlotte, N.C., that was filled with false claims about the integrity of mail-in voting and the policy positions of his Democratic opponent, Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Why Catherine O’Hara and Cecily Strong Love Oblivious People
description: In a conversation, the Emmy nominees O’Hara, of “Schitt’s Creek,” and Strong, of “Saturday Night Live,” talk about balancing their love of outsize characters with their aversion to the spotlight.
content: The 72nd Primetime Emmy Awards will be given out on Sept. 20, so we’re talking to pairs of nominated actors as we look ahead to the ceremony. (Whatever it ends up being.) For a full list of Emmy nominees and other coverage of TV’s top awards, visit nytimes.com/Emmys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: First Documented Coronavirus Reinfection Reported in Hong Kong
description: The patient did mount an immune response to the new infection, however, and did not experience symptoms.
content: A 33-year-old man was infected a second time with the coronavirus more than four months after his first bout, the first documented case of so-called reinfection, researchers in Hong Kong reported Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Trump’s Campaign of Chaos
description: The president’s behavior is that of a desperate man.
content: I smell the stench of panic on Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Fahim Abed
title: Afghan Soccer Official, Charged With Sexual Abuse, Evades Arrest
description: The unsuccessful operation against Keramuddin Keram, whom players accused of rape and other abuses, showed the limited reach of the national government.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The powerful former chairman of Afghanistan’s soccer federation, who faces criminal charges of sexual abuse of female players, eluded capture by Afghan Special Operations officers on Sunday, laying bare the tenuous reach of the national government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum and Danny Hakim
title: The N.Y. attorney general asked a judge to order Eric Trump to testify about the Trump family business.
description: The New York State attorney general’s office has asked a judge to order President Trump’s son Eric to testify under oath in an inquiry into the Trump family’s real estate firm, court papers show.
content: The New York State attorney general’s office has asked a judge to order President Trump’s son Eric to testify under oath in an inquiry into the Trump family’s real estate firm, court papers show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Donner
title: View From the I.M.F. — In a Crisis Like No Other, Gender Still Counts
description: “The economics of gender equality is a book already written,” said Kristalina Georgieva, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund.
content: — Kristalina Georgieva, managing director of the International Monetary Fund
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Sarah Mervosh
title: Wisconsin Reels After Police Shooting and Second Night of Protests
description: Jacob Blake, a Black resident of Kenosha, was shot in the back, setting off condemnations from Wisconsin’s governor and Joe Biden, the Democrats’ presidential nominee.
content: KENOSHA, Wis. — When Annie Hurst stepped outside her house on Sunday night, she saw something that made her scream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Republicans Renominate Trump in a Roll Call Infused With Fear-Mongering
description: As 336 party delegates gathered to renominate the president, some warned that “Joe Biden is hiding in the dark, waiting to take the lives of our unborn babies.”
content: [Our guide to tonight’s RNC schedule and speakers, including where and how to watch.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zengerle
title: Donald Trump Jr. Is Ready. But for What, Exactly?
description: Of all the president’s children, he has the strongest connection to the politics, voters and online disinformation ecosystem that put his father in the White House. What will he do with it?
content: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Justin Townes Earle, Singer-Songwriter in Father’s Footsteps, Dies at 38
description: He released eight alt-country albums as a solo artist, seeking to emerge from the long shadow of the outlaw country star Steve Earle.
content: Justin Townes Earle, an accomplished alt-country singer and songwriter who was a son of the country-rock firebrand Steve Earle, died on Thursday at his home in Nashville. He was 38.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Waldbieser
title: Getting Your Kids to Turn It Down a Notch (or Several)
description: A mother raising a deaf son paradoxically lives in a house full of noise. But she learns from him how to unplug and disconnect.
content: In my house, mornings begin with a bang. Usually, from a door being thrown open, followed by the belligerent bellow, “Ma! Milk!” that sounds more like it came from a pro wrestler than the pajama-clad 6-year-old crashing into my bedroom. It’s 6 a.m. (if I’m lucky) and my eyes are still shut, but my ears are wide open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: ‘The Big Short 2.0’: How Hedge Funds Profited Off the Pain of Malls
description: As the pandemic accelerated the demise of some brick-and-mortar retailers, a group of investors profited handsomely from their travails.
content: Catie McKee was nervous. It was last October, and the 31-year-old hedge fund analyst, who had been scrutinizing the mortgages on the nation’s malls, was convinced that some of those malls would default on their loans. She and her colleagues had even bet a substantial amount of money on that likelihood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Honey May Ease Coughs and Other Respiratory Symptoms
description: A review of studies confirms an old home remedy: honey for colds.
content: Honey is a traditional home remedy for colds. Now a review of studies provides scientific evidence that honey does indeed have a modest but significant beneficial effect on coughs and other respiratory symptoms.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Florida Judge Strikes Down Order Requiring Schools to Physically Reopen Amid Covid-19 Risks
description: Quarantine rules are expanding around the world, but not in America. The virus is circulating in Gaza. Researchers in Hong Kong find that in rare cases, a person can get reinfected.
content: A Florida judge ruled on Monday that the state’s requirement that public schools open their classrooms for in-person instruction violates the Florida constitution because it “arbitrarily disregards safety” and denies local school boards the ability to decide when students can safely return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Dancing Ban Aimed at Young People Breaks the Rhythm of Many Older Italians
description: In many Italian towns and villages, outdoor dance halls are a central part of life for the older generation. But a pandemic rule intended to stop crowding in nightclubs is forcing them to close their dance floors.
content: LEGNAGO, Italy — Raffaele Leardini, 72, slipped on his pink linen shirt, buttoned it up to the middle of his chest, combed back his hair and set off on Thursday with his wife to Caribe, their favorite outdoor dance hall. When they arrived, they found the club open but the dance floor sealed off with red and white tape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Your Sourdough Deserves This
description: Made of a fabric-like paper, these bread bags from the Italian company Uashmama give bread cozy spot on the dinner table.
content: The buyers for Food52 have found an unusual item, a bag from Tuscany for keeping bread. It’s fashioned of sturdy washable paper by Uashmama, a company that specializes in the material and uses it for a range of products. The bread bag is made in various colors and in two sizes, suitable for round or oval loaves, cut sections and rolls (but not baguettes). And it comes with a cute terra cotta insert, which, when warmed in the oven, keeps the bread warm in the bag for maybe half an hour. You can use the bags for storing bread, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere, Sheri Fink, Katie Thomas and Maggie Haberman
title: F.D.A. Allows Expanded Use of Plasma to Treat Coronavirus Patients
description: The move came on the eve of the Republican convention and after President Trump pressed the agency to move faster to address the pandemic.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Sunday gave emergency approval for expanded use of antibody-rich blood plasma to help hospitalized coronavirus patients, allowing President Trump, who has been pressuring the agency to move faster to address the pandemic, to claim progress on the eve of the Republican convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: After a Covid Scare, an Olympic Hopeful Recovers Her Optimism
description: Sunisa Lee was afraid she was infected with the coronavirus. She emerged from isolation with renewed resilience and a brand-new outlook on training.
content: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year. Read Lee’s first installments here and here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Why Trump’s Approval Ratings on the Economy Remain Durable
description: Despite the recession, polling data and interviews with voters and political analysts suggest that a confluence of factors are raising the president’s standing on the economy issue.
content: It is an enduring political question amid a pandemic recession, double-digit unemployment and a recovery that appears to be slowing: Why does President Trump continue to get higher marks on economic issues in polls than his predecessors Barack Obama, George W. Bush and George H.W. Bush enjoyed when they stood for re-election?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Cleared to Play, Mets Have a Busy Week Ahead
description: After four games were postponed, the Mets have nine games scheduled for the next six days, including two doubleheaders at the Yankees.
content: The Mets returned to work on Monday, practicing at Citi Field and preparing for a busy stretch of games after four postponements in a row. A player and a staff member tested positive last week for the coronavirus, but the team said Monday that no other staff members or players had tested positive since then.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What Are Your Kids Drawing?
description: We’d love to see the ways your children are interpreting and reflecting on the coronavirus pandemic.
content: If your kids are making art that’s at all about the pandemic — drawings of their school-from-home work spaces, abstractions about anxiety, pictures of their friends drawn at a safe social distance — we’d love to see it. We may feature some responses in the Coronavirus Schools Briefing in the coming days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Raichlen
title: Charcuterie With All of the Smoke but None of the Meat
description: American chefs are exploring the possibilities of plant-based salumi, and even home chefs can try their hand.
content: Watermelon ham. Radish prosciutto. Jerky sticks made from burdock root.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Jarred Vegetables From the Chef Missy Robbins
description: Perfect for an antipasto platter, these preserved tomatoes, artichokes and zucchini also work nicely in a sandwich.
content: Though Missy Robbins is known for homemade pasta at her two Brooklyn restaurants, Lilia and Misi, she is also an expert when it comes to preparing vegetables. Jarred marinated and grilled artichokes (16 ounces, $17), slow-roasted tomatoes in olive oil (12 ounces, $18), and lemon and garlic marinated zucchini (6 ounces, $16) are superb additions to salads, antipasto platters, sandwiches and even pasta dishes. The preserves are all from MP Specialties, one of the departments in her online store, and available for pickup at locations throughout the tristate area.
source.name: The New York Times

title: America’s Monuments, Reimagined for a More Just Future
description: With colonialist statues being toppled in America and beyond, T asked five artists to envision a different kind of memorial, one that embodies this moment of reckoning.
content: ACCORDING TO DATA compiled by the Southern Poverty Law Center, some 100 monuments to Confederate generals and politicians have been removed from American public land since June 2015, when Dylann Roof, a then 21-year-old white supremacist, murdered nine Black parishioners in a mass shooting at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C., a city that, at the time, still flew the Confederate flag over its Statehouse. More than a third of these monuments have been removed since May 25 of this year alone, when a Minnesota police officer named Derek Chauvin, who has been charged with second-degree murder, was caught on video kneeling on the neck of George Floyd, an unarmed Black man, for more than eight minutes while Floyd pleaded for his life. (As a point of comparison, for the nearly 100 years between 1923 and 2015, only nine such monuments were removed.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.7 Million Homes in California
description: An Edwardian house in San Francisco, a modern beach retreat in Malibu and a renovated 1945 home in La Jolla.
content: Built in 1906, this home reflects the architectural trends of early 20th-century San Francisco. Its facade resembles those of the Victorian-era, Queen Anne-style homes in the city, but with less ornamentation, much like the Arts & Crafts homes that became popular in California a few years later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: How Zeynep Tufekci Keeps Getting the Big Things Right
description: Dr. Tufekci, a computer programmer who became a sociologist, sounded an early alarm on the need for protective masks. It wasn’t the first time she was right about something big.
content: When the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention told Americans in January that they didn’t need to wear masks, Dr. S. Vincent Rajkumar, a professor at the Mayo Clinic and the editor of the Blood Cancer Journal, couldn’t believe his ears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Bar Tools
description: With most indoor bars still closed, the next best thing is the do-it-yourself version. Here’s what you need to get started.
content: The time to toast the days of late summer is now. But with indoor bars still largely off limits, finding a well-crafted cocktail is more difficult than it used to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Andrew Higgins
title: Day After Mass Protests, Belarus Arrests Opposition Activists
description: After rallies in the capital, Minsk, drew 100,000 people, the authorities arrested two more opposition activists and summoned others for questioning.
content: MINSK, Belarus — Security forces in Belarus on Monday arrested two of the last high-profile opposition figures not already in jail for protesting against the country’s authoritarian president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko. The arrests came as a senior United States diplomat met with the embattled president’s most prominent opponent, who fled the country under duress earlier this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: A Reminder to Enfold Yourself in Small Comforts
description: “I iron our masks” and other tales of magical thinking and pandemic-era coping.
content: NASHVILLE — The scent of sun-dried sheets fresh off the clothesline can completely change my state of mind. Like the sense of well-being that comes over me when a song from my youth is playing on the radio, the smell of line-dried sheets takes me home to Alabama, back to a time when all my beloved elders were still alive, still humming as they shook out a wad of damp bedsheets and pinned them to the line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan and Katie Glueck
title: Biden and Harris will be tested regularly for the coronavirus.
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Kamala Harris will be tested regularly for the coronavirus as Election Day approaches, the Biden campaign said on Monday, a day after a senior Biden official said Mr. Biden had not yet been tested.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Kamala Harris will be tested regularly for the coronavirus as Election Day approaches, the Biden campaign said on Monday, a day after a senior Biden official said Mr. Biden had not yet been tested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Toronto Raptors Complete Sweep of Undermanned Nets
description: The defending champions ended the Nets’ season with a 150-122 win, but Toronto awaits the status of All-Star point guard Kyle Lowry ahead of its series with Boston after he left with an injury.
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Norman Powell scored 29 points, his fellow reserve Serge Ibaka added 27 points and 15 rebounds and the Toronto Raptors cruised into the Eastern Conference semifinals by routing the Nets, 150-122, on Sunday to complete a sweep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Trump’s Big Week
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: I’m happy to be back in your inboxes after an August break. And I’m grateful to my colleagues who did such a nice job filling in. Now let’s dive into the 2020 campaign …
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: Plot Twist! Why 2004 Was a Surprising Year for Movies
description: Before franchises dominated completely, great actors joined flashy directors in originals like “Collateral” and M. Night Shyamalan’s “The Village.”
content: No one else is going to say it, so allow me: 2004 was a good movie year. So good that this month’s edition of The Box is a sequel to last month’s. That one was set the late June weekend that “Fahrenheit 9/11” opened up top and “The Notebook” was still a sleeper. This one finds us in the first full weekend of August, when “Collateral” knocked “The Village” to second place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
title: Kellyanne Conway, Long-Serving Trump Aide, Is Leaving the White House
description: Ms. Conway said she was stepping away from her role as the president’s counselor to spend more time with her four teenage children.
content: Kellyanne Conway, President Trump’s counselor and one of his longest-serving and most visible aides, said on Sunday night that she planned to leave the White House next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Katherine Rosman
title: Private Infighting Roils Owners of Washington N.F.L. Team
description: The team’s principal owner, Daniel Snyder, wanted to overhaul it this season, but, as court filings show, that task has been complicated by fractions between him and the franchise’s other shareholders.
content: Michael MacCambridge spent five years writing his 2005 history of the N.F.L., visiting team after team around the country. From the stability of the Pittsburgh Steelers to the emerging dynasty in New England, he learned that great franchises thrived and overcame obstacles with a mix of talent, trust and patience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Belarus Protests, Russia’s Vaccine, Christchurch Sentencing: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: At Least 14 Killed After Suicide Bombers Hit Philippines
description: Soldiers and civilians were among the dead. The explosions occurred in a town plaza and near a cathedral targeted in a suicide bombing last year.
content: MANILA — Two powerful explosions set off by two suicide bombers ripped through heavily populated areas of a southern Philippine island on Monday, killing at least 14 people and wounding 75 others in a known stronghold of the extremist group Abu Sayyaf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Radical Break From Tradition: Trump Stages Part of His Convention From the White House
description: But President Trump’s convention speech and those of Melania Trump and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo are only the latest examples of how Mr. Trump has further blurred the lines between the government and his campaign.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump appeared from the White House twice on the opening night of the Republican National Convention on Monday, and he will deliver his acceptance speech this week from the South Lawn. Melania Trump will speak from the Rose Garden. And even Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will beam in to endorse the president from a rooftop in Jerusalem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Frank Cullotta, Mobster Turned Memoirist and YouTuber, Dies at 81
description: Mr. Cullotta testified in organized crime cases, and went on to write memoirs, give tours and speak about his life on his YouTube channel, “Coffee with Cullotta.” He died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: As Evictions Loom, Lawyers Are Gearing Up to Help
description: With a federal moratorium coming to an end, legal aid lawyers say they are preparing to defend renters in housing court.
content: Just a few weeks ago, Jessie Reed was worried about being evicted from her Omaha apartment with her three young children. Her landlord had already tried to force her out in May when she stopped paying rent after quitting her job at an Omaha Steaks warehouse. One of her children has severe asthma, and Ms. Reed was worried she would unwittingly catch the coronavirus at work and transmit it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mónica R. Goya
title: Roaming Through Lanzarote’s Otherworldly Vineyards
description: The desolate beauty of the winemaking tradition on Lanzarote, the easternmost of the Canary Islands, is evidence of human resilience in the face of adversity.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Mónica R. Goya shares a collection of images from the Spanish island of Lanzarote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Saturday: A CNN Special and ‘Tesla’
description: CNN examines the state of women’s rights in America, 100 years since the suffrage movement. And Ethan Hawke stars in an unorthodox biopic.
content: WOMEN REPRESENTED: THE 100 YEAR BATTLE FOR EQUALITY 10 p.m. on CNN. Last Tuesday, the United States celebrated the 100th anniversary of the ratification of the 19th Amendment, which gave women the right to vote. To commemorate the milestone, CNN’s Erin Burnett takes a look back at the history of the women’s suffrage movement, and examines where the country currently stands on gender equality and how far it still has to go. The 90-minute special features conversations with Melinda Gates, Roxane Gay, Cecile Richards and others who discuss the prospects of America’s first woman president, inequities in the workplace and the legacy of the #MeToo movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and David M. Halbfinger
title: On Mideast Trip, Pompeo Mixes Diplomacy With Partisan Politics
description: The secretary of state’s five-day tour is intended to discuss regional peace and security. He also planned to use Jerusalem as a backdrop for an address to the Republican National Convention.
content: JERUSALEM — The backdrop for Secretary of State Mike Pompeo’s planned speech to the Republican National Convention promised to be spectacular: sweeping views of Jerusalem’s Old City, with the domes and spires of its holy sites.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Surge in Shootings
description: Gun violence in the U.S. typically rises in summer, but the problem has been especially fierce this year. Why?
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joel Santo Domingo
title: 5 Simple Ways to Improve Your Wi-Fi
description: So long, sluggish internet.
content: For anyone used to working in a traditional office, working from home has revealed just how telecommuting-unfriendly a living space can be. While it may be uncomfortable to sit in a bad office chair or type under dim overhead lighting, a bad internet connection can really impede your productivity — or even grind it to a halt. Between Zoom meetings and remote learning, coupled with more members of the household hogging up bandwidth, you might have noticed a slower-than-usual connection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Aleksei Navalny, Putin Critic in a Coma, Was Poisoned, German Doctors Say
description: Once again, a prominent critic of Moscow has mysteriously fallen ill. And once again, poison appears to be the culprit.
content: BERLIN — Aleksei A. Navalny, the outspoken Russian dissident who fell into a coma last week, was a victim of poisoning, German doctors said Monday, adding him to the ranks of Russians stricken by mystery illness after drawing the wrath of Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Daughter of Immigrants to Be 1st Black Woman on N.J. Supreme Court
description: Fabiana Pierre-Louis, 39, will also be the only Black judge currently seated on the state’s highest court.
content: Fabiana Pierre-Louis, a daughter of Haitian immigrants, is on track to become the first Black woman to sit on New Jersey’s highest court, serving at a time when the state and the country remain deeply divided over racial and economic injustice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry and Hiroko Masuike
title: Republicans, Kenosha, Aleksei Navalny: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: As Census Count Resumes, Doubts About Accuracy Continue to Grow
description: Officials project optimism. But a chorus of experts says the pandemic and politics could lead to a deeply flawed count.
content: WASHINGTON — With the 2020 census into its final stage, more than one in three people hired as census takers have quit or failed to show up.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump’s Rush to Proclaim Covid-19 Treatments
description: Citing the president’s pressure on the F.D.A. to approve the expanded use of plasma, readers worry that hasty measures without sufficient testing will put patients at risk.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Scott Peterson’s Death Sentence Is Overturned
description: The California Supreme Court upheld Mr. Peterson’s 2004 conviction for killing his wife, Laci Peterson, but it said the judge’s mistakes had denied him an impartial jury during sentencing.
content: The California Supreme Court on Monday overturned the death penalty for Scott Peterson, who was found guilty in 2004 of killing his pregnant wife, Laci, in a notorious case that became fodder for the tabloids and cable news and spawned at least one made-for-TV movie.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why TikTok Will Lose
description: The Chinese-owned video app plans to sue the Trump administration over its order to force a sale. It faces long odds.
content: Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: 4 Years of Catastrophic Fires in California: ‘I’m Numb’
description: For the eight million residents of the San Francisco Bay Area, a ring of fire across Northern California feels inescapable.
content: FREMONT, Calif. — Residents of the San Francisco suburbs are packing emergency “go bags” and drawing up inventories of their belongings, dreading the idea that they might need proof for an insurance adjuster if their homes burn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Peisner
title: Bettye LaVette Didn’t Know the Beatles’ ‘Blackbird.’ Then It Helped Her Fly.
description: Ten years ago, the Fab Four’s song about civil rights gave the soul singer a creative spark. Now she’s releasing an album of tracks originally popularized by Black women.
content: In the summer of 2010, the soul singer Bettye LaVette stepped onstage at the Hollywood Bowl in Los Angeles with a 32-piece string section behind her and performed a four-decade-old song she’d only just learned: the Beatles’ “Blackbird.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah and Marie Fazio
title: Kenosha Police Shooting of Black Man Is Investigated by Wisconsin Authorities
description: The man was hospitalized in serious condition, the authorities said, and Kenosha declared an overnight curfew as protests grew around the city.
content: The Wisconsin Department of Justice is investigating the police shooting on Sunday of a Black man in Kenosha, Wis., as he opened the door of a parked vehicle on a residential street, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: Why N.Y.C.’s Future May Hinge on Businesses Outside Manhattan
description: The four other boroughs, hit hard by the pandemic, have increasingly played a crucial role in the city’s expanding economy.
content: When the coronavirus outbreak crippled New York City’s economy, it not only emptied the streets and office towers in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: He Helped Fellow Immigrants See the World. Now His Business Is Sinking.
description: Small, minority-owned travel agencies in New York, already pummeled by internet websites, are facing further devastation because of the pandemic.
content: Ahmed Al-Hassan was country-hopping in Africa when the coronavirus pandemic shut down travel across much of the continent. He and his wife, Rosy, faced an indefinite stay at an airport in Nairobi, Kenya, with no easy way to return home to New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Not the Convention, or the Election, North Carolina Republicans Hoped For
description: The G.O.P. was supposed to be celebrating in the state this week. Instead, it is trying to hold on to a Senate seat and lift President Trump’s low poll numbers.
content: [Our guide to tonight’s RNC schedule and speakers, including where and how to watch.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: LeBron James and a Multimillion-Dollar Push for More Poll Workers
description: More Than a Vote, a group of athletes headlined by LeBron James, is launching a campaign to address poll worker shortages and the need to keep polling stations open in Black electoral districts.
content: More Than a Vote, a collective of athletes headlined by LeBron James that is fighting to combat voter suppression, will announce a multimillion-dollar initiative to increase the number of poll workers in Black electoral districts ahead of November’s general election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: How to Watch the Republican National Convention
description: Speakers on Night 1 include Nikki Haley, Senator Tim Scott and Donald Trump Jr., as well as President Trump, who is expected to appear four nights in a row.
content: The Republican National Convention starts on Monday. Unlike the Democratic convention last week, which was almost entirely virtual, it will be held partly in person in Charlotte, N.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Wehner
title: Conservatives Have Only One Choice in 2020
description: After what we have seen during Trump’s first term, any true conservative should be appalled by the prospect of a second.
content: “You’re a traitor to the cause.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Stelter
title: Trump’s Favorite Four-Letter Word
description: The president didn’t always love the word, “hoax.” Now it serves him, but not the public, well.
content: The Trump era is the hoax era. But not in the way he or his cheerleaders claim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin, Alexander Burns and Annie Karni
title: Nominating Trump, Republicans Rewrite His Record
description: President Trump and his party engaged in sweeping revisionism about his management of the coronavirus, his record on race relations and much else. And they painted a dystopian picture of what the nation would look like if Joseph R. Biden Jr. were president.
content: President Trump and his political allies mounted a fierce and misleading defense of his political record on the first night of the Republican convention on Monday, while unleashing a barrage of attacks on Joseph R. Biden Jr. and the Democratic Party that were unrelenting in their bleakness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerry Seinfeld
title: Jerry Seinfeld: So You Think New York Is ‘Dead’
description: (It’s not.)
content: When I got my first apartment in Manhattan in the hot summer of 1976, there was no pooper-scooper law, and the streets were covered in dog crap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Belarus Protests Test Limits of Lukashenko’s Brutal, One-Man Rule
description: For 26 years, President Aleksandr Lukashenko has built a regime in his own eccentric, authoritarian image. Now he faces the greatest challenge yet to his hold on power.
content: He jokes about running a dictatorship. He makes his generals salute his teenage son, who shares his penchant for dressing in military uniforms. He commands a brutal security service that makes people disappear. And when Covid-19 arrived, he told his people to play hockey, drive tractors and not worry about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Biden reiterates a plan to raise taxes on ‘anybody making over $400,000.’
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic presidential nominee and former vice president, seemed to suggest that most taxpayers would avoid increases if he is elected president in November, according to an interview with ABC News that aired on Sunday night.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic presidential nominee and former vice president, seemed to suggest that most taxpayers would avoid increases if he is elected president in November, according to an interview with ABC News that aired on Sunday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: 1,100-Year-Old Treasure Is Unearthed by Teenagers in Israel
description: The discovery of hundreds of gold coins dating to the ninth century could help archaeologists better understand the history of the region.
content: The treasure needed to be secured. So the hoard of 425 gold coins was stowed in a clay jar, its lid secured with a nail, and stashed in the sands of what is now central Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Officer Is Fired After TikTok Videos Show His Arrest of Black Woman
description: The officer “did not meet our core values” in the way he acted, the police department in Gwinnett County, Ga., said.
content: A police officer in Georgia was fired as of Friday after videos on TikTok that drew millions of views showed him using a Taser in the arrest of a Black woman, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson, Nicholas Fandos, Alan Rappeport, Luke Broadwater and Emily Cochrane
title: Key Highlights of Louis DeJoy’s Testimony to a House Panel
description: Louis DeJoy testified before the House Oversight Committee on Monday, where lawmakers continued to express concern about postal changes that could complicate mail-in voting.
content: A defiant Louis DeJoy, under tough questioning from Democrats, defended the cost-cutting measures he put in place as postmaster general and rejected suggestions that the changes were intended to influence the 2020 election by making mail-in voting less reliable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Social Media Offered Bannon’s Group a Tool to Promote Ties to Trump and Raise Millions
description: An encounter with an administration official. A photo with Donald Trump Jr. A chat with the president himself. Officials at We Build the Wall turned a stream of postings into a gusher of donations.
content: Since the arrest of his former senior political adviser Stephen K. Bannon, President Trump has tried to distance himself from the nonprofit group that raised more than $25 million for the supposed purpose of building a wall along the border with Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Has the Detroit Institute of Arts Lost Touch With Its Home Town?
description: Critics say the museum is not doing enough to relate to the predominantly Black city in which it’s located or to the people of color on its staff.
content: The Detroit Institute of Arts had just avoided selling off parts of its collection to help pay the debts of the city that owned it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: Young Adults’ Pandemic Mental Health Risks
description: In a new C.D.C. survey, 18- to 24-year-olds reported the highest levels of symptoms of anxiety and depression, and a quarter of them said they had seriously considered suicide.
content: Yes, these are hard times, and everyone is stressed, but new data suggest that young adults — both those who are going back to college and those who are not — may be suffering particularly hard when it comes to mental health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Ana Swanson
title: TikTok Sues U.S. Government Over Trump Ban
description: The suit escalates a bitter back-and-forth between the popular video app and American officials.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — TikTok sued the U.S. government on Monday, accusing the Trump administration of depriving it of due process when President Trump used his emergency economic powers to issue an executive order that will block the app from operating in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Africa Celebrates the End of the Wild Poliovirus (but Not the End of All Polio)
description: A virus that once paralyzed tens of thousands of children a year is said to have been eradicated on the African continent, though a minor strain  still infects hundreds.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — Africa is set to announce that it has stamped out wild poliovirus after a three-decade campaign against a disease that once paralyzed 75,000 children on the continent every year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump releases a largely detail-free agenda for a second term.
description: President Trump, who has struggled to answer basic questions about what he would do with a second term, on Sunday night released a list of vague statements about his agenda for four more years.
content: President Trump, who has struggled to answer basic questions about what he would do with a second term, on Sunday night released a list of vague statements about his agenda for four more years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: Let the Culture Wars Begin. Again.
description: Long before Trump, there was Pat Buchanan. The 2020 Republican convention is looking strangely like the 1992 edition.
content: The Republican convention at last begins this week, and much of it will be virtual, which makes it very 2020. Yet as strange as it is to say — and bear with me here — something about this moment brings to mind the Republican convention of 1992.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Scope of California Wildfires Is Staggering
description: Fires have chewed through 1.4 million acres in the state this year. By this point in 2019, 56,000 acres had burned.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California on Monday addressed a state besieged by wildfires of staggering scale and spread, assuring residents that “we’ve deployed every resource at our disposal” as the number of active fires grew to 625.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Trump’s Reality TV Show Would Like You to Forget About Reality for a While
description: Until Nov. 4, to be precise.
content: Gail Collins: So Bret, did Joe Biden’s convention speech make you comfortable? The idea was to reassure folks like me about health care reform and raising the minimum wage but not so much that folks like you would consider a conservative revolt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘I May Destroy You’ and ‘Love Island’
description: Michaela Coel’s acclaimed series wraps up its first season. And the American version of a popular British dating show returns.
content: LOVE ISLAND 8 p.m. on CBS. The British dating show’s American spinoff returns for a second season tonight with a two-hour premiere. The host Arielle Vandenberg welcomes a new cast of single men and women to an isolated location where they’ll live together in proximity under the watchful eye of the show’s many cameras. For this installment, participants will be sequestered in the Cromwell hotel in Las Vegas, not an exotic international site, because of the coronavirus pandemic, which also delayed the season’s debut. A provisional coupling will kick things off, then the contestants will have be paired up at each subsequent recoupling ceremony to remain in contention for the $100,000 prize. They’ll also have to ingratiate themselves to viewers and their fellow “islanders,” whose votes occasionally determine who departs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: N.Y.P.D. Records, No Longer Secret, Shed Light on Misconduct
description: Nearly 324,000 complaints against  police officers were published online. The Times's police bureau chief  explains what that means.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zoë Beery
title: When the World Shut Down, They Saw It Open
description: The pandemic has made work and social life more accessible for many. People with disabilities are wondering whether virtual accommodations will last.
content: This April, Maria Sotnikova attended her first Seder: a virtual dinner held over the videoconferencing app Webex. Though she has many Jewish friends, she had never been asked to share in the Passover ritual before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: The Nets’ Bridge Year Is Over. Now, the Real Work Begins.
description: Injuries to key players lowered the Nets’ ceiling this season. But the looming returns of Kyrie Irving and Kevin Durant bring with them higher expectations.
content: If the Nets fall in the postseason, but most of the key players aren’t there to see it, did the Nets really fall?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Baseball’s Most Unusual Season Is Halfway Over
description: The Dodgers are 22-8 after 30 games of a 60-game season that will be remembered for postponed games, health-driven rules and expanded playoffs.
content: The logo of the 2020 All-Star Game looms over the action at Dodger Stadium from a billboard above the right-field pavilion. The game was supposed to be held last month in Los Angeles, for the first time in 40 years, but the coronavirus pandemic canceled it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Europe Tried to Limit Mass Layoffs, but the Cuts Are Coming Anyway
description: Despite furlough schemes that have kept tens of millions of people employed, a tsunami of job cuts is about to hit as companies downsize.
content: PARIS — At BP, 10,000 jobs. At Lufthansa, 22,000. At Renault, 14,600.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Summer in a Bowl
description: Make Vallery Lomas’s latest, a gorgeous succotash, that’s everything good about late August, crammed onto a plate.
content: Good morning! This is Tejal, writing to you from Los Angeles, where the summer produce is nudging me toward this gorgeous succotash (above) from Vallery Lomas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Bringing a ‘Broad City’ Approach to Energizing the Youth Vote
description: A new voting project from Ilana Glazer is aimed at millennials and Gen Z members who just need to be persuaded to show up.
content: Young people who vote: They are the holy grail of any presidential campaign, but regularly getting them energized and excited is a yet-to-be-cracked formula.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: This isn’t the convention, or the election, North Carolina Republicans had hoped for.
description: For most of the past decade, North Carolina was a showcase for the Republican Party’s growth — its strength in the suburbs, in rural areas and in races up and down the ballot proving that it could dominate in parts of the country where demographics favored the Democrats. Now it could be a victim of its own excess.
content: For most of the past decade, North Carolina was a showcase for the Republican Party’s growth — its strength in the suburbs, in rural areas and in races up and down the ballot proving that it could dominate in parts of the country where demographics favored the Democrats. Now it could be a victim of its own excess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Dustin Johnson Rebounds With a Rout at the Northern Trust
description: After a July stretch in which he missed the cut at one start and withdrew from the next, Johnson won by 11 strokes.
content: NORTON, Mass. — Dustin Johnson had just missed a straightforward six-foot birdie putt on the ninth hole at the Northern Trust golf tournament Sunday, squandering a chance to extend his commanding lead in the event’s final round. Then, walking across a street to the 10th tee, he tripped and stumbled before regaining his footing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson, Nicholas Fandos and Neil Vigdor
title: In House testimony, DeJoy calls Trump’s comments about mail-in voting ‘not helpful.’
description: Louis DeJoy, the postmaster general, appeared before lawmakers again on Monday, this time testifying to the Democratic-run House oversight committee. He faced much tougher questioning than he did on Friday, when he testified before a committee of the Republican-run Senate.
content: Louis DeJoy, the postmaster general, appeared before lawmakers again on Monday, this time testifying to the Democratic-run House oversight committee. He faced much tougher questioning than he did on Friday, when he testified before a committee of the Republican-run Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Ilana Glazer brings a ‘Broad City’ approach to energizing young voters.
description: Young people who vote: They are the holy grail of any presidential campaign, but regularly getting them energized and excited is a yet-to-be-cracked formula.
content: Young people who vote: They are the holy grail of any presidential campaign, but regularly getting them energized and excited is a yet-to-be-cracked formula.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham, Elizabeth Dias and Frances Robles
title: Jerry Falwell Jr.’s Leadership at Liberty Appears Near End
description: One of President Trump’s most prominent evangelical supporters, Mr. Falwell denied reports he had resigned from the university.
content: The leadership of Jerry Falwell Jr., one of the most prominent evangelical supporters of President Trump, appeared to be nearing an end at Liberty University after a report emerged on Monday of sexual indiscretions involving Mr. Falwell, his wife and a pool attendant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Outdoors in Bushwick, Gardens of Theatrical Discovery
description: Replete with music, masks and vibrant costumes, “Quince” and “Beast Visit” turn urban green spaces into stages for festivity.
content: Once upon a time I thought all theater was Broadway. My early years as a freelance critic taught me differently. One summer I caught a tiny, low-budget production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” in a Brooklyn church. Another time I ventured to a nondescript location in Hell’s Kitchen to see an experimental performance-art piece. In both cases I left unsure and a bit frightened, to suddenly see the limits of my perspective, to realize that my conception of theater was so terribly, naïvely narrow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Trump Keeps Promoting a Drug Order That No One Has Seen
description: The president’s campaign has made his efforts to lower prescription drug prices a centerpiece of his re-election pitch, but the executive order remains unseen.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump has made his executive order tying prescription drug prices in the United States to the prices paid in Europe and other developed nations — and the ensuing war that has broken out with the pharmaceutical industry — a centerpiece of his campaign for re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorothy J. Gentry
title: Dallas Wings Guard Allisha Gray Is a Gamer, in Every Way
description: In her fourth W.N.B.A. season, Gray said she was ready to do “whatever helps the team.”
content: It takes more than big names to win games in the W.N.B.A. The New York Times is talking to players across the league who are making an impact in their own way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh and Hari Kumar
title: A Lawyer’s Tweets Put India’s Supreme Court on Trial and Him at Risk of Imprisonment
description: Prashant Bhushan, a prominent lawyer who criticized India’s Supreme Court, could be sentenced to jail after he was found in contempt.
content: NEW DELHI — First, the firebrand lawyer wrote a one-sentence tweet opining about the Indian Supreme Court’s role in eroding freedoms in the world’s largest democracy. Two days later, he tweeted a photo of the court’s chief justice astride a Harley-Davidson owned by a political ally of the country’s powerful prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Nothing Beats the Smell of Freshly Baked Cookies
description: Leonelli Focacceria e Pasticceria is now selling its chocolate chip cookies in a ready-to-bake kit.
content: Like many restaurateurs and chefs trying to survive the pandemic, Jonathan Benno has gone into the meal kit business. Along with dinner dishes to assemble at home, his Leonelli Focacceria e Pasticceria in the NoMad section of Manhattan is offering frozen chocolate chip cookie dough, ready to bake. Leave space on the baking sheet: The dough makes hefty confections that spread to about four inches in diameter and are thickly peppered with bits of Italian chocolate. You can’t bake just one; the kit comes with a baker’s dozen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Concepción de León
title: Black Chefs Are Landing More Cookbook Deals. Is That Enough?
description: African-American food writers are seeing more interest among publishers, but the ones who have been burned by the experience warn that the industry’s problems go further than advances and paychecks.
content: When Nicole Taylor’s agent suggested three years ago that she write a Juneteenth cookbook, Ms. Taylor, a food writer, shelved the idea. She didn’t think any publisher would buy it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni, Maggie Haberman and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Republican National Convention: What to Watch For
description: With a program heavy on all things Trump and overseen by a president highly attuned to how events play on television, the convention offers a test of whether he can appeal beyond his base.
content: [Our guide to tonight’s RNC schedule and speakers, including where and how to watch.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Farago and Delphine Danhier
title: Vibrant Fashions to Brighten One’s Look and Mood
description: Combinations of Slim Aarons-inspired shades, retro stripes and abstract patterns that bestow a sense of freedom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: Virus Response Fueling G.O.P. Bid to Retake New Mexico Seat
description: A district flipped by Democrats is suddenly in play again as Republicans mobilize opposition to pandemic measures, signaling the tenuous hold Democrats have on some seats they picked up in 2018.
content: LAS CRUCES, N.M. — When Democrats in New Mexico swept elections just two years ago, flipping the Republican-held congressional district that stretches across more than half the state ranked among their biggest wins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: Partial Zoom Outage Is Fixed After School Disruptions
description: Some school districts and colleges also had outages on Canvas, an online learning platform.
content: A widespread outage on the video call service Zoom caused problems for students, teachers and professors around the United States on Monday morning, the first day of classes for many schools and universities that are reopening online because of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Medication and Lifestyle May Lower Breast Cancer Risk
description: There is compelling evidence that two classes of drugs normally prescribed following breast cancer treatment can also help prevent the disease.
content: Mammography is a valuable tool for finding breast cancer when it is still confined to the breast and highly amenable to cure. But no matter how good the odds for survival may be with early detection, I’m quite certain women would rather not develop breast cancer in the first place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Chen
title: Gen Z and Millennials: Tell Us if You Plan to Vote and Why
description: Submit a video with your answers and they may be featured in an upcoming New York Times event.
content: Young people have been on the forefront of political movements for generations. Yet for almost as long, voter turnout in the United States among people under 30 has been low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerry Garrett
title: Winning Indy 500s and Surfing Couches
description: After winning on Sunday, the Japanese driver Takuma Sato revealed he had spent much of the year crashing at a friend’s house in Indianapolis because of the pandemic.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — Takuma Sato, the Japanese driver who has won more than $4.5 million in prize money with two victories now at the Indianapolis 500 since 2017, certainly misses the comforts of home — his home, anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Annie Karni
title: The Republican convention is underway. Here’s how to watch.
description: Republican National Committee members and delegates gathered inside the Charlotte Convention Center Monday morning for their roll call to renominate President Trump.
content: Republican National Committee members and delegates gathered inside the Charlotte Convention Center Monday morning for their roll call to renominate President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Doctors are offering direct access in the pandemic, for those who can afford it.
description: Concierge care, which offers personalized medical services for people who can afford it, has grown fast in the pandemic as patients seek direct access to physicians.
content: Concierge care, which offers personalized medical services for people who can afford it, has grown fast in the pandemic as patients seek direct access to physicians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Leatherby
title: Why Are Coronavirus Cases Decreasing? Experts Say Restrictions Are Working
description: Infection rates in the United States remain among the world’s highest, but numbers are down. All states driving the decrease have at least some local mask mandates.
content: Infection rates in the United States remain among the world’s highest, but numbers are down. All states driving the decrease have at least some local mask mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer, Nadja Popovich and Brian Palmer
title: How Decades of Racist Housing Policy Left Neighborhoods Sweltering
description: Redlining helped reshape the urban landscape of U.S. cities. It also left communities of color far more vulnerable to rising heat.
content: Redlining helped reshape the urban landscape of U.S. cities. It also left communities of color far more vulnerable to rising heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Senator Chris Murphy Is Worried We’re Seeing Democracy’s Last Stand
description: “Frankly, democracy is supposed to elevate the issues that are personally important to people.”
content: “Frankly, democracy is supposed to elevate the issues that are personally important to people.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $3.7 Million in California
description: An Edwardian house in San Francisco, a modern beach retreat in Malibu and a renovated 1945 home in La Jolla.
content: An Edwardian house in San Francisco, a modern beach retreat in Malibu and a renovated 1945 home in La Jolla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: DeJoy Defends Postal Service Changes at Heated Hearing
description: Postmaster General Louis DeJoy testified before the House Oversight Committee on cost-cutting measures and delivery delays, and said he did not plan to restore mail sorting machines in Postal Service locations.
content: Postmaster General Louis DeJoy testified before the House Oversight Committee on cost-cutting measures and delivery delays, and said he did not plan to restore mail sorting machines in Postal Service locations.
source.name: The New York Times
